title: $A enjoys another RBA rally
text:
Fri, Aug 7, 2015, 6:49 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A enjoys another RBA rally AAP – 59 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has rallied on expectations the Reserve Bank is less likely to cut the cash rate again any time soon. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the local unit was trading at 73.78 US cents, up from 73.30 cents on Thursday. 
The RBA's quarterly statement on Friday indicated it expects the unemployment has already peaked, and the bank maintained economic growth in 2016 and 2017 is likely to reach three per cent or more. 
RBC Capital Markets analyst Adam Cole said the RBA statement was a key driver for the local currency on a day when most traders were waiting for US employment figures. 
"The RBA's quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy further diluted the central banks' easing bias despite a lower implied trend growth rate," he said. 
"Its discussions on the cyclical position of the economy were also notably more positive than previously." 
The key focus for the market during the offshore session on Friday night will be US non farm payrolls employment data. 
It will be a crucial indicator for when the US Federal Reserve will raise its interest rate, with most analysts predicting a September rate hike following comments from a couple of Fed officials this week. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 92.04 Japanese yen, up from Thursday's close of 91.50 yen, and at 67.54 euro cents, up from 67.16 euro cents. 
Meanwhile, the Australian bond market was weaker. 
Nomura strategist Andrew Ticehurst said the RBA's latest economic forecasts resulted in the bond market pricing in a reduced prospect of another cash rate cut. 
"The market was quite surprised to see some modest upward revisions to the RBA's inflation forecasts, with underlying inflation seen as being at the mid-point of the RBA's target band rather than in the lower half of the target band," he said. 
At 1630 AEST on Friday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.120 (implying a yield of 2.880 per cent), down from 97.140 (2.860 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.010 (1.990 per cent), down from 98.020 (1.980 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook ANZ's biggest share price fall since GFC AAP
